92 class Breakpoint (object):
93 """
94 Base class for breakpoints.
95 Here's the breakpoints state machine.
96  
97 @see: L{CodeBreakpoint}, L{PageBreakpoint}, L{HardwareBreakpoint}
98  
99 @group Breakpoint states:
100 DISABLED, ENABLED, ONESHOT, RUNNING
101 @group State machine:
102 hit, disable, enable, one_shot, running,
103 is_disabled, is_enabled, is_one_shot, is_running,
104 get_state, get_state_name
105 @group Information:
106 get_address, get_size, get_span, is_here
107 @group Conditional breakpoints:
108 is_conditional, is_unconditional,
109 get_condition, set_condition, eval_condition
110 @group Automatic breakpoints:
111 is_automatic, is_interactive,
112 get_action, set_action, run_action
113  
114 @cvar DISABLED: I{Disabled} S{->} Enabled, OneShot
115 @cvar ENABLED: I{Enabled} S{->} I{Running}, Disabled
116 @cvar ONESHOT: I{OneShot} S{->} I{Disabled}
117 @cvar RUNNING: I{Running} S{->} I{Enabled}, Disabled
118  
119 @type DISABLED: int
120 @type ENABLED: int
121 @type ONESHOT: int
122 @type RUNNING: int
123  
124 @type stateNames: dict E{lb} int S{->} str E{rb}
125 @cvar stateNames: User-friendly names for each breakpoint state.
126  
127 @type typeName: str
128 @cvar typeName: User friendly breakpoint type string.
129 """

539 class CodeBreakpoint (Breakpoint):
540 """
541 Code execution breakpoints (using an int3 opcode).
542  
543 @see: L{Debug.break_at}
544  
545 @type bpInstruction: str
546 @cvar bpInstruction: Breakpoint instruction for the current processor.
547 """
548  
549 typeName = 'code breakpoint'
550  
551 if win32.arch in (win32.ARCH_I386, win32.ARCH_AMD64):
552 bpInstruction = '\xCC' # int 3
553  
  • E251 Unexpected spaces around keyword / parameter equals (in 4 places)
554 def __init__(self, address, condition = True, action = None):
555 """
556 Code breakpoint object.
557  
558 @see: L{Breakpoint.__init__}
559  
560 @type address: int
561 @param address: Memory address for breakpoint.
562  
563 @type condition: function
564 @param condition: (Optional) Condition callback function.
565  
566 @type action: function
567 @param action: (Optional) Action callback function.
568 """
569 if win32.arch not in (win32.ARCH_I386, win32.ARCH_AMD64):
570 msg = "Code breakpoints not supported for %s" % win32.arch
571 raise NotImplementedError(msg)
572 Breakpoint.__init__(self, address, len(self.bpInstruction),
573 condition, action)
574 self.__previousValue = self.bpInstruction
575  
576 def __set_bp(self, aProcess):
577 """
578 Writes a breakpoint instruction at the target address.
579  
580 @type aProcess: L{Process}
581 @param aProcess: Process object.
582 """
583 address = self.get_address()
584 self.__previousValue = aProcess.read(address, len(self.bpInstruction))
585 if self.__previousValue == self.bpInstruction:
586 msg = "Possible overlapping code breakpoints at %s"
587 msg = msg % HexDump.address(address)
588 warnings.warn(msg, BreakpointWarning)
589 aProcess.write(address, self.bpInstruction)
590  
591 def __clear_bp(self, aProcess):
592 """
593 Restores the original byte at the target address.
594  
595 @type aProcess: L{Process}
596 @param aProcess: Process object.
597 """
598 address = self.get_address()
599 currentValue = aProcess.read(address, len(self.bpInstruction))
600 if currentValue == self.bpInstruction:
601 # Only restore the previous value if the int3 is still there.
602 aProcess.write(self.get_address(), self.__previousValue)
603 else:
604 self.__previousValue = currentValue
605 msg = "Overwritten code breakpoint at %s"
606 msg = msg % HexDump.address(address)
607 warnings.warn(msg, BreakpointWarning)
608  
609 def disable(self, aProcess, aThread):
610 if not self.is_disabled() and not self.is_running():
611 self.__clear_bp(aProcess)
612 super(CodeBreakpoint, self).disable(aProcess, aThread)
613  
614 def enable(self, aProcess, aThread):
615 if not self.is_enabled() and not self.is_one_shot():
616 self.__set_bp(aProcess)
617 super(CodeBreakpoint, self).enable(aProcess, aThread)
618  
619 def one_shot(self, aProcess, aThread):
620 if not self.is_enabled() and not self.is_one_shot():
621 self.__set_bp(aProcess)
622 super(CodeBreakpoint, self).one_shot(aProcess, aThread)
623  
624 # FIXME race condition here (however unlikely)
625 # If another thread runs on over the target address while
626 # the breakpoint is in RUNNING state, we'll miss it. There
627 # is a solution to this but it's somewhat complicated, so
628 # I'm leaving it for another version of the debugger. :(
629 def running(self, aProcess, aThread):
630 if self.is_enabled():
631 self.__clear_bp(aProcess)
632 aThread.set_tf()
633 super(CodeBreakpoint, self).running(aProcess, aThread)

979  
980 # XXX FIXME
981 #
982 # The implementation of function hooks is very simple. A breakpoint is set at
983 # the entry point. Each time it's hit the "pre" callback is executed. If a
984 # "post" callback was defined, a one-shot breakpoint is set at the return
985 # address - and when that breakpoint hits, the "post" callback is executed.
986 #
987 # Functions hooks, as they are implemented now, don't work correctly for
988 # recursive functions. The problem is we don't know when to remove the
989 # breakpoint at the return address. Also there could be more than one return
990 # address.
991 #
992 # One possible solution would involve a dictionary of lists, where the key
993 # would be the thread ID and the value a stack of return addresses. But we
994 # still don't know what to do if the "wrong" return address is hit for some
995 # reason (maybe check the stack pointer?). Or if both a code and a hardware
996 # breakpoint are hit simultaneously.
997 #
998 # For now, the workaround for the user is to set only the "pre" callback for
999 # functions that are known to be recursive.
1000 #
1001 # If an exception is thrown by a hooked function and caught by one of it's
1002 # parent functions, the "post" callback won't be called and weird stuff may
1003 # happen. A possible solution is to put a breakpoint in the system call that
1004 # unwinds the stack, to detect this case and remove the "post" breakpoint.
1005 #
1006 # Hooks may also behave oddly if the return address is overwritten by a buffer
1007 # overflow bug (this is similar to the exception problem). But it's probably a
1008 # minor issue since when you're fuzzing a function for overflows you're usually
1009 # not interested in the return value anyway.
1010  
1011 # TODO: an API to modify the hooked function's arguments
1012  
  • E302 Expected 2 blank lines, found 1

4026

4029 not all arguments to the hooked function will be of the same size.

4722 def break_on_error(self, pid, errorCode):
4723 """
4724 Sets or clears the system breakpoint for a given Win32 error code.
4725  
4726 Use L{Process.is_system_defined_breakpoint} to tell if a breakpoint
4727 exception was caused by a system breakpoint or by the application
4728 itself (for example because of a failed assertion in the code).
4729  
4730 @note: This functionality is only available since Windows Server 2003.
4731 In 2003 it only breaks on error values set externally to the
4732 kernel32.dll library, but this was fixed in Windows Vista.
4733  
4734 @warn: This method will fail if the debug symbols for ntdll (kernel32
4735 in Windows 2003) are not present. For more information see:
4736 L{System.fix_symbol_store_path}.
4737  
4738 @see: U{http://www.nynaeve.net/?p=147}
4739  
4740 @type pid: int
4741 @param pid: Process ID.
4742  
4743 @type errorCode: int
4744 @param errorCode: Win32 error code to stop on. Set to C{0} or
4745 C{ERROR_SUCCESS} to clear the breakpoint instead.
4746  
4747 @raise NotImplementedError:
4748 The functionality is not supported in this system.
4749  
4750 @raise WindowsError:
4751 An error occurred while processing this request.
4752 """
4753 aProcess = self.system.get_process(pid)
  • E221 Multiple spaces before operator
4754 address = aProcess.get_break_on_error_ptr()
4755 if not address:
4756 raise NotImplementedError(
4757 "The functionality is not supported in this system.")
4758 aProcess.write_dword(address, errorCode)

4778  
4779 def resolve_exported_function(self, pid, modName, procName):
4780 """
4781 Resolves the exported DLL function for the given process.
4782  
4783 @type pid: int
4784 @param pid: Process global ID.
4785  
4786 @type modName: str
4787 @param modName: Name of the module that exports the function.
4788  
4789 @type procName: str
4790 @param procName: Name of the exported function to resolve.
4791  
4792 @rtype: int, None
4793 @return: On success, the address of the exported function.
4794 On failure, returns C{None}.
4795 """
4796 aProcess = self.system.get_process(pid)
4797 aModule = aProcess.get_module_by_name(modName)
4798 if not aModule:
4799 aProcess.scan_modules()
4800 aModule = aProcess.get_module_by_name(modName)
4801 if aModule:
4802 address = aModule.resolve(procName)
4803 return address
4804 return None
